data.title: Cody Miller is IU's first U.S. Olympic swimmer in 40 years
authors: David Woods, david.woods@indystar.com, The Indianapolis Star
data.meta_description: Indiana University waited 40 years to place one swimmer on the U.S. Olympic team
data.text:
Indiana University waited 40 years to place one swimmer on the U.S. Olympic team. The Hoosiers might wait 24 hours for a second.

Cody Miller, born with a deformity that diminishes his lung capacity, finished second in the men’s 100-meter breaststroke Monday night in the U.S. Olympic Trials at Omaha, Neb.

That secured the IU graduate’s spot on the team heading to Rio de Janeiro. The Hoosiers also had had the fastest qualifier in the women’s 100 breaststroke,19-year-old Lilly King.

Kevin Cordes took the men’s race in 59.18. Miller, fourth after 50 meters, finished fast to post 59.26. The top two make the Olympics.

“I’ve had a lot of closing speed this meet, so I was really focused on trying to hammer that last 20 meters and try and get my hand on the wall,” Miller said in IU news release. “I got the job done, got on the team and just trying to soak it in right now. It’s very surreal.”

The Hoosiers had four swimmers on the U.S. team at Montreal in 1976: Jim Montgomery, Gary Hall, Charlie Keating and Jennifer Hooker. Montgomery won a gold medal in the 100-meter freestyle, becoming the first man under 50 seconds.

“Very few people we have coached train harder with more passion and determination than Cody,” Indiana coach Ray Looze said. “His meaning to our program is immeasurable and we’re so happy for his family and the Hoosier nation on such an outstanding accomplishment.”

Miller, 24, grew up in Las Vegas as the son of a single mother. She could not swim and wanted to be sure her son could. He learned to swim early, and the sport helped broaden his chest and develop his rib cage.

He was diagnosed with pectus excavatum, or a sunken-in chest. Sometimes surgery is performed on those with the condition, but Miller never had that done. Most breaststrokers are 6-3 to 6-5, and he is 5-10.

“Every kid dreams of this and the fact that I’m not very big and have a lot of disadvantages, it’s unbelievable that I’m here to do this,” Miller said.

In semifinals of the women’s 100 breaststroke, King won her semifinal in 1:05.94 and was fastest overall. Molly Hannis won the other semifinal in 1:06.24.

Getting the last of eight spots for Tuesday’s final was Miranda Tucker, who has left the IU program. As a freshman this year, she was second to King in the NCAA 200-yard breaststroke.

“I took it out a little fast, but other than that, I’m happy with the time and to be qualified first,” said King, who won two NCAA titles in March.

In another final, Amy Bilquist will try to become the first ever to make the Olympics out of Carmel’s long-dominant swim program. The 18-year-old graduated from Carmel High School last year and just completed her freshman year at University of California.

She won her semifinal of the 100 backstroke in 59.85 and is seeded No. 3 behind Olivia Smoliga, 59.16, and Kathleen Baker, 59.36. Georgia’s Smoliga is the NCAA champion in the 50- and 100-yard freestyles. Olympic gold medalists Missy Franklin and Natalie Coughlin barely made the final as the No. 7 and 8 qualifiers.

Bilquist had the No. 2 time of prelims, 59.67. Coincidentally, she was in a lane adjacent to former Carmel teammate Claire Adams, whose Olympic quest was over almost before it began.

Adams, 17, broke her hand Tuesday. She swam anyway and was 46th overall in 1:02.46. She set a world junior (under-18) record of 59.58 in winning a national title last summer and was the No. 4 seed.

In another semifinal, IU’s Blake Pieroni was 12th overall in the men’s 200 freestyle in 1:48.44, missing the cut to eight. He qualified for semifinals with the No. 7 time, 1:47.93. This was his best shot to make the Olympic team because top six are customarily selected for the 800 freestyle relay.

Evansville native Michael Klueh, 29, was 10th in 1:48.14. Zane Grothe, who trains with the IU team, was 16th in 1:50.24.

Maxime Rooney, 18, whose world junior record is 1:47.10, was ninth in 1:47.98.

Carmel Swim Club’s Drew Kibler was 33rd in prelims in 1:50.01 – fastest in the nation by a 16-year-old this year. He came to Omaha seeded 48th.

Rooney and Kibler should be selected to the U.S. team for the Junior Pan Pacific Championships, set for Aug. 24-27 at Kihei, Hawaii.

Ledecky makes team, misses record

Katie Ledecky earned her first spot for Rio, winning the the 400 freestyle in 3:58.98, third-fastest time in history. Leah Smith claiming an Olympic berth by finishing in 4:00.65. IU graduate Lindsay Vrooman was fourth in 4:08.99.

Kelsi Worrell became the University of Louisville’s first Olympic swimmer, winning the 100 butterfly in 56.48. Dana Vollmer, 28, a four-time gold medalist who gave birth to her first child 16 months ago, was second in 57.21.

The Associated Press contributed to this story.

Call IndyStar reporter David Woods at (317) 444-6195. Follow him on Twitter: @DavidWoods007.
